Every now and then, if you’re lucky, you’ll leave a theater with bittersweet but ultimately joyful tears streaming down your face, perhaps wishing you’d worn waterproof mascara. That was my predicament, at least, after catching a preview of “Maybe Happy Ending,” the most original and enchanting new musical to arrive on Broadway in years.
No maybe about it — Maybe Happy Ending has theatrical magic
Maybe Happy Ending is a show that succeeds by thinking small and feeling big, embracing the intimate story it wants to tell rather than inflating it beyond recognition.
There is no "maybe" about it when it comes to the brilliance and winning charm

"“Maybe Happy Ending” [is] a ravishing addition to the catalog of Broadway nerdicals. The term is high praise, honoring supersmart, usually small-scale shows — like “Fun Home,” “The Band’s Visit” and “Kimberly Akimbo” — that nevertheless have big emotional impact.
The result is a show that is touching without being mawkish, funny without being silly, and moving without being manipulative—a rare combination in contemporary musical theater.

The musical achieves something rare: It makes you care deeply about characters who are, literally, machines. The story of two obsolete robots finding connection is both whimsical and surprisingly moving.
A sweet romcom by Hue Park and Will Aronson opens on Broadway. When a theater reviewer uses the word “sweet” or any of its synonyms, it’s most often in a derogatory way.

The musical, which follows two helper-bots who fall in love, is a tender meditation on what it means to be human, to love and to let go.
